Title: Withering Depths
Pitch_Text:
Play as Prea, a defenseless being trapped in the infected and hostile depths. Use the pheromones found in your environment to interact with various platforms.

Withering Depths is a PC platformer combining puzzles and "die-and-retry" gameplay, featuring a horizontal-scrolling camera.
The game design aims to evoke a sense of unknown, unpredictability, and hostility
SumUp_Text:
Withering Depths was my first first-year project, and it allowed me to find my footing in several areas of game development, such as teamwork on a shared project, the Unity engine and C#.

It introduced me to the basics of gameplay design and taught me how to build a 2D controller.

Project completed as part of my study at Rubika Valenciennes
Realisation_Text:
As the only programmer in the team, I was in charge of all the programming as well as some aspects of the game design. Here are some key points on this project :

•The 2D controller : In order to get the specific feeling we were aiming for, the controller was developed entirely without using Unity’s Rigidbody, which was a significant challenge given my limited knowledge at the time. Using Raycasts, I implemented jump buffering, coyote time and a lateral offset system that slightly shifts the player when they hit the corner of a platform, allowing them to continue their jump if space permits.

•The UI and inputs : For maintainability, they were implemented using Unity's new input system.

• The cameras : We were aiming for a precise control over our camera behavior, which led to the creation of a custom camera script. Although simple, it allowed us to switch between cameras when entering trigger zones and to restrict the camera to predefined areas.

The gameplay elements : True to our concept, the mechanics were quite challenging to build as a beginner. Withering Depths features three platform types, each reacting differently to three distinct pheromones the player can switch between. Together, these systems created several technical challenges, such as dynamic state management and collision handling, made more difficult by the absence of a Rigidbody on the player.

•The save system : Since Withering Depths is partly a "die-and-retry", we implemented a system using PlayerPrefs to store the number of deaths and completion time for each level.
Amelioration_Text:
One major mistake in this project was not using a Game Manager to centralize certain behaviors, which greatly reduced the readability and maintainability of my scripts. Due to my limited experience at the time, several elements, such as platform interactions, were poorly optimized or even placed in scripts that were not responsible for their logic such as implementing platform effects directly inside the controller script.

Another mistake comes from that same script: because it served as the main component, I invested a large portion of development time into it, which made it difficult to read in certain places. I did not yet understand the importance of splitting and structuring code, which resulted in the controller being contained in one large script.

However, these mistakes helped me understand the importance of clear architecture from the start of a project and pushed me to adopt more modular practices in my later work.
